=== America ===
====Canada==== Section 15 (1) of the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] states that "every individual is equal before and under the law and has the right to equal protection and equal benefit of the law without discrimination and, in particular, without discrimination based on{{Nbsp}}... age" (as well as other protected classes).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/Const/page-15.html|title=Consolidated federal laws of canada, Access to Information Act|first=Legislative Services|last=Branch|date=30 July 2015|website=laws-lois.justice.gc.ca|access-date=30 April 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110221331/http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/Const/page-15.html|archive-date=10 January 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref>
In Canada, Article 718.2, clause (a)(i), of the [[Criminal Code]] defines as aggravating circumstances, among other situations, "evidence that the offence was motivated by{{Nbsp}}... age".<ref>[http://www.laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/C-46/bo-ga:l_XXIII-gb:s_718//en#anchorbo-ga:l_XXIII-gb:s_718 Canadian Criminal Code] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706181639/http://www.laws.justice.gc.ca/en/showdoc/cs/C-46/bo-ga%3Al_XXIII-gb%3As_718//en |date=6 July 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/international/Pages/Canada.aspx Canada] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120716080129/http://www.agediscrimination.info/international/Pages/Canada.aspx |date=16 July 2012 }}. Agediscrimination.info (12 December 2006). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
Mandatory retirement was largely ended in Canada in December 2011,<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=568 "Tories in Canada end forced retirement, decades of 'age discrimination{{'"}}] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718004027/http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=568 |date=18 July 2012 }}. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> but 74% of Canadians still consider age discrimination to be a problem.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=657 Canadians believe employers discriminate against older applicants]. Agediscrimination.info (23 July 2012). Retrieved on 24 July 2012.</ref>
Retirement age for Canadian airline pilots is provided by each airline with some set to age 60, but changes to the [[Canadian Human Rights Act]] have restricted retirement age set by the airlines.<ref>{{cite web|author=Vanessa Lu|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2013/01/24/air_canada_pilots_can_continue_flying_past_age_60_under_new_rules.html|title=Air Canada pilots can continue flying past age 60 under new rules|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=January 24, 2013|access-date=November 5, 2013}}</ref>
==== Colombia ==== Measures taken to prevent the spread of [[COVID-19 pandemic in Colombia|COVID-19]] were especially strict on older people in Colombia. The government prohibited anyone over 70 years of age from leaving their house.<ref>{{Cite chapter | last1=Galeano | first1=E | last2=Zuluaga | first2=M | last3=Saldarriaga-Ruiz | first3=G | chapter=Envejecimiento y Covid-19: los debates que impone el confinamiento de los mayores a un mundo envejeciente |url=http://bibliotecadigital.udea.edu.co/bitstream/10495/17635/4/UribeAlejandro_2020_PolifoniaPensarPandemia.pdf |title=Polifonía para pensar una pandemia |publisher=Universidad de Antioquia, Fondo Editorial FCSH de la Facultad de Ciencias Sociales y Humanas |year=2020|isbn=978-958-5157-17-0 |location=|pages=145–166}}</ref> Amid public backlash, the restriction was taken to court and overturned.
====United States==== {{main|Age discrimination in the United States}} In the United States, each [[List of states and territories of the United States|state]] has its own laws regarding age discrimination, and there are also federal laws.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/international/Pages/USA.aspx USA]. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> In California, the [[California Fair Employment and Housing Act of 1959|Fair Employment and Housing Act]] forbids unlawful discrimination against persons age 40 and older. The FEHA is the principal California statute prohibiting employment discrimination, covering employers, [[Trade union|labor organizations]], [[Employment agency|employment agencies]], apprenticeship programs and/or any person or entity who aids, abets, incites, compels, or coerces the doing of a discriminatory act. In addition to age, it prohibits employment discrimination based on race or color; religion; national origin or ancestry, [[disability]], mental type or medical condition; marital status; sex or sexual orientation; and pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions.<ref>[http://finduslaw.com/california_fair_employment_and_housing_act_feha_government_code_12900_12996 California Fair Employment and Housing Act] FindLaw.</ref> Although there are many protections for age-based discrimination against older workers (as shown above) there are less protections for younger workers.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
The [[District of Columbia]] and twelve states (California, Florida, [[Iowa]], Hawaii, [[Kansas]], [[Louisiana]], [[Maine]], [[Minnesota]], [[Nebraska]], [[New Mexico]], New York, and [[Vermont]]) define age as a specific motivation for hate crimes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anti-Defamation League State Hate Crime Statutory Provisions (2005)|url=http://www.adl.org/learn/hate_crimes_laws/State_Hate_Crime_Statutory_Provisions_chart.pdf|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629085842/http://www.adl.org/learn/hate_crimes_laws/State_Hate_Crime_Statutory_Provisions_chart.pdf|archive-date=29 June 2011|access-date=22 May 2009|df=dmy-all}} {{small|(23.8 KB)}} (See page 1, section "Other", note 2) Retrieved on 21 May 2009</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Everyday Fears – A Survey of Violent Hate Crimes in Europe and North America|url=http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/discrimination/pdf/everyday-fears-080805.pdf|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060112034643/http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/discrimination/pdf/everyday-fears-080805.pdf|archive-date=12 January 2006|access-date=22 May 2009|df=dmy-all}} {{small|(1.96 MB)}} McClintock, Michael (See pages 84 and 122, Appendix 10, "Others", note 2) Retrieved on 21 May 2009</ref>
The federal government restricts age discrimination under the [[Age Discrimination in Employment Act]] of 1967 (ADEA). That law provides certain employment protections to workers who are over the age of forty, who work for an employer who has twenty or more employees. For protected workers, the ADEA prohibits discrimination at all levels of employment, from recruitment and hiring, through the employment relationship, and through decisions for layoffs or termination of the employment relationship.<ref name="auto1" /> An age limit may only be legally specified for protected workers in the circumstance where age has been shown to be a "[[bona fide occupational qualification]] [BFOQ] reasonably necessary to the normal operation of the particular business" (see {{usc|29|623(f)(1)}}). In practice, BFOQs for age are limited to the obvious (hiring a young actor to play a young character in a movie) or when public safety is at stake (for example, in the case of age limits for pilots and bus drivers). The ADEA does not stop an employer from favoring an older employee over a younger one, even when the younger one is over 40 years old.<ref name="auto2" /> [[File:Jimmy Carter participates in a bill signing ceremony - NARA - 178763.tif|thumb|President [[Jimmy Carter]] signing legislation against mandatory retirement in 1978]] [[Mandatory retirement]] due to age is generally unlawful in the United States, except in certain industries and occupations that are regulated by law, and are often part of the government (such as military service and federal police agencies, such as the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]). [[Minnesota]] has statutorily established mandatory retirement for all judges at age 70 (more precisely, at the end of the month a judge reaches that age). The [[Minnesota Legislature]] has had the constitutional right to set judicial retirement ages since 1956, but did not do so until 1973, setting the age at 70.<ref name="auto">{{cite news|last=Stassen-Berger|first=Rachel E.|date=July 7, 2015|title=Minnesota judges aren't making a fuss about retirement rule|newspaper=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press|Pioneer Press]]|location=[[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul, MN]]|url=http://www.twincities.com/politics/ci_28448632/rachel-stassen-berger-minnesota-judges-arent-making-fuss|access-date=December 28, 2015}}</ref> The Federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which became law in 1986, ended mandatory age-related retirement at age 70 for many jobs, not including the Minnesota judiciary;<ref name="auto" /> another exception was all postsecondary institutions (colleges, etc.) This exception ended on December 31, 1993.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Weinberg|first1=Sharon L.|last2=Scott|first2=Marc A.|year=2013|title=The Impact of Uncapping of Mandatory Retirement on Postsecondary Institutions|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.3102/0013189X13497993|journal=Educational Researcher|volume=42|issue=6|pages=338–348|doi=10.3102/0013189X13497993|s2cid=13265704}}</ref><ref>Sanjek, Roger (2009). Gray Panthers. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 185.</ref> The Fair Treatment for Experienced Pilots Act (Public Law 110-135) went into effect on December 13, 2007, raising the mandatory retirement age for pilots to 65 from the previous 60.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=10072|title=FAA Statement on Pilot Retirement Age|date=14 December 2007|access-date=21 October 2012}}</ref>
In September 2016, California passed state bill AB-1687, an anti-ageism law taking effect on 1 January 2017, requiring "commercial online entertainment employment" services that allow paid subscribers to submit information and resumes (such as [[IMDB Pro]]), to honor requests to have their ages and birthdays removed. The bill was supported by [[SAG-AFTRA]]'s former and current presidents [[Ken Howard]] and [[Gabrielle Carteris]], who felt that the law would help to reduce ageism in the entertainment industry.<ref name="thr-imdblaw">{{cite web|title=California Enacts Law Requiring IMDb to Remove Actor Ages on Request|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/california-enacts-law-requiring-imdb-932330|access-date=15 November 2016|website=The Hollywood Reporter|date=24 September 2016}}</ref> On 23 February 2017, U.S. District Judge Vince Girdhari Chhabria issued a stay on the bill pending a further trial, claiming that it was "difficult to imagine how AB 1687 could not violate the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]" because it inhibited the public consumption of factual information.<ref name="thr-lawstruck">{{cite web|title=Judge Pauses Enforcement of IMDb Age Censorship Law|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/judge-pauses-enforcement-imdb-age-censorship-law-978797|access-date=23 February 2017|website=The Hollywood Reporter|date=22 February 2017}}</ref> In February 2018, Girdhari ruled that the law was unconstitutional, arguing that the state of California "[had] not shown that partially eliminating one source of age-related information will appreciably diminish the amount of age discrimination occurring in the entertainment industry." The ruling was criticized by SAG-AFTRA, alleging that the court "incorrectly concluded there were no material disputed factual issues, while precluding the parties from acquiring additional evidence or permitting the case to go to trial". The ruling was eventually appealed, but the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals upheld it in 2020.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Pedersen|first=Erik|date=20 February 2018|title=California's IMDb Age Law Violates First Amendment, Federal Court Rules; SAG-AFTRA "Extremely Disappointed" – Update|language=en-US|work=Deadline|url=https://deadline.com/2018/02/imdb-age-law-violates-first-amendment-california-1202296413/|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref>
=== Asia ===
==== Australia ==== In regards to employment, discrimination on the basis of age is illegal in each of the states and territories of Australia. At the national level, Australia is party to a number of international treaties and conventions that impose obligations to eliminate age discrimination.<ref name="bfr1">{{cite book|last1=Bittman|first1=Michael|url=http://www.jamesmahmudrice.info/SPRCR601.pdf|title=The Recruitment of Older Australian Workers: A Survey of Employers in a High Growth Industry|last2=Flick|first2=Mardi|last3=Rice|first3=James|publisher=Social Policy Research Centre, University of New South Wales|year=2001|isbn=978-0-7334-1908-9|location=Sydney|pages=14–15}}</ref>
The Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986 established the Australian Human Rights Commission and bestows on this Commission functions in relation to a number of international treaties and conventions that cover age discrimination.<ref name="bfr1" /><ref name="ahrc">{{cite web|title=Legislation | Australian Human Rights Commission|url=https://www.humanrights.gov.au/our-work/legal/legislation|access-date=27 April 2013|work=Australian Human Rights Commission}}</ref> During 1998-1999, 15% of complaints received by the Commission under the Act were about discrimination on the basis of age.<ref name="bfr1" />
Age discrimination laws at the national level were strengthened by the [[Age Discrimination Act 2004]], which helps to ensure that people are not subjected to age discrimination in various areas of public life, including employment, the provision of goods and services, education, and the administration of Australian government laws and programs. The Act, however, does provide for exemptions in some areas, as well as providing for positive discrimination, that is, actions which assist people of a particular age who experience a disadvantage because of their age.<ref name="ahrc" />
In 2011, the position of Age Discrimination Commissioner was created within the Australian Human Rights Commission. The Commissioner's responsibilities include raising awareness among employers about the beneficial contributions that senior Australians as well as younger employees can make in the workforce.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=431 In Australia, new age discrimination laws have been passed by the Federal Parliament; a position of Age Discrimination Commissioner has been created in the Australian Human Rights Commission for the first time]. Agediscrimination.info (26 May 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> Every state in Australia has a probationary plate system for drivers. This is allowed because the Age Discrimination Act says that, in some circumstances, treating someone differently because of their age won't be against the law. This is known as an exemption and includes:
*things done in compliance with Commonwealth laws, including laws about taxation, social security and migration *things done in compliance with state and territory laws *certain health and employment programmes *youth wages or direct compliance with industrial agreements and awards.<ref>[https://www.humanrights.gov.au/know-your-rights-age-discrimination When is age discrimination not against the law?] humanrights.gov.au Retrieved 7 March 2017</ref>
====Philippines==== At least two bills have been filed before the [[16th Congress of the Philippines]] seeking to address age discrimination in employment in the country. The Blas Ople Policy Center, a non-government organization, asserts that responsibilities of making a livelihood in a household has shifted to younger members of the family due to bias against hiring people older than 30 years of age. The organization also added that age discrimination contributes to the unemployment rate and acts as a hurdle to [[inclusive growth]] in the country. [[Overseas Filipino Workers]] returning from abroad seeking to find work in the country were tagged as vulnerable to age discrimination.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mateo|first1=Janvic|title=Law vs age discrimination in employment sought|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2014/06/11/1333431/law-vs-age-discrimination-employment-sought|access-date=15 April 2015|work=The Philippine Star|date=11 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Lopez|first1=Ron|title=End age discrimination, Congress urged|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/end-age-discrimination-congress-urged/|access-date=15 April 2015|publisher=Manila Bulletin|date=8 May 2014}}</ref>
===Europe===
====European Union==== The [[European Union|European]] citizenship provides the right to protection from discrimination on the grounds of age. According to Article 21-1 of the [[Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union|Charter of Fundamental Rights]] of the [[European Union]] [[s:Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union#CHAPTER III. EQUALITY]], "any discrimination based on any ground such as{{Nbsp}}… age, shall be prohibited".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.europarl.europa.eu/charter/pdf/text_en.pdf |title=Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union (official text) }} {{small|(80.6 KB)}}</ref>
Additional protection against age discrimination comes from the Framework Directive 2000/78/EC. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of age in the field of employment.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/legislation/Pages/ECLegislation.aspx EC Legislation]. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
====Germany==== On 18 August 2006, the General Equal Treatment Act (Allgemeines Gleichbehandlungsgesetz, AGG) came into force. The aim of the AGG is to prevent and abolish discrimination on various grounds including age.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/international/Pages/Germany.aspx Germany]. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
A recent{{when|date=December 2020}} study suggested that youths in Germany feel the brunt of age discrimination.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=580 Young in Germany feel brunt of age discrimination]. Agediscrimination.info (23 January 2012). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
====France==== In France, Articles 225-1 through 225-4 of the [[Penal code|Penal Code]] detail the [[criminalization|penalization]] of Ageism, when it comes to an age discrimination related to the [[Consumption (economics)|consumption]] of a [[good (economics)|good]] or service, to the exercise of an economic activity, to the [[labour economics|labor market]] or an [[intern]]ship, except in the cases foreseen in Article 225-3.<ref>[http://195.83.177.9/code/liste.phtml?lang=uk&c=33&r=3716 French Penal Code (Legifrance)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817181231/http://195.83.177.9/code/liste.phtml?lang=uk&c=33&r=3716 |date=17 August 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/codes/id/LEGISCTA000006165298/2009-03-17/|title=Section 1 : Des discriminations (Articles 225-1 à 225-4) - Légifrance|website=www.legifrance.gouv.fr}}</ref><ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/international/Pages/France.aspx France]. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
====Belgium==== In [[Belgium]], the Law of 25 February 2003 "tending to fight discrimination" punishes Ageism when "a difference of treatment that lacks objective and reasonable justification is directly based on{{Nbsp}}... age". Discrimination is forbidden when it refers to providing or offering a good or service, to conditions linked to work or employment, to the appointment or [[promotion (rank)|promotion]] of an employee, and yet to the access or participation in "an economic, social, cultural or political activity accessible to the public" (Article 2nd, § 4). [[Incitement]] to discrimination, to [[hatred]] or to violence against a person or a group on the grounds of{{Nbsp}}... age (Article 6) is punished with [[incarceration|imprisonment]] and/or a [[fine (penalty)|fine]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.stop-discrimination.info/fileadmin/pdfs/Nationale_Inhalte/Belgium/Gesetz/25.02.2003.pdf |title=Belgium Law of 25 Feb 2003 against discrimination |language=fr}} {{small|(76.5 KB)}}</ref><ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/international/Pages/Belgium.aspx Belgium]. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> Nevertheless, employment opportunities are worsening for people in their middle years in many of these same countries, according to Martin Kohli ''et al.'' in ''Time for Retirement'' (1991).
====Sweden==== The Swedish Discrimination Act (2008:567) was enacted in 2008 and states that: "the purpose of the Act is to combat discrimination and in other ways promote equal rights and opportunities regardless of sex{{Nbsp}}... or age."<ref>{{cite web |title=Official translation of the Swedish Discrimination Act |url=https://www.government.se/4a788f/contentassets/6732121a2cb54ee3b21da9c628b6bdc7/oversattning-diskrimineringslagen_eng.pdf |website=Government Offices of Sweden |access-date=14 October 2020}}</ref> In Sweden, considering the increased proportion of older people, ageism is also discussed in the context of healthcare sector and health profession students such as nursing students.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Classic Tool, New Opportunities: A Psychometric Analysis of a Swedish Online Version of the Aging Semantic Differential Scale |journal=Research on Aging |year=2020 |doi=10.1177/0164027520963618 |last1=Holmberg |first1=Christopher |last2=Wolf |first2=Axel |last3=Eide |first3=Camilla |last4=Großschädl |first4=Franziska |last5=Schüttengruber |first5=Gerhilde |last6=Patel |first6=Harshida |last7=Heckemann |first7=Birgit |volume=43 |issue=9–10 |pages=378–387 |pmid=34524931 |doi-access=free }}</ref>
====United Kingdom==== [[File:Barbara Robb c.1941.jpg|thumb|[[Barbara Robb]], founder of the [[Aid for the Elderly in Government Institutions]] pressure group]] [[Barbara Robb]], founder of the British pressure group, [[Aid for the Elderly in Government Institutions]] (AEGIS), compiled ''Sans Everything: A Case to Answer'', a controversial book detailing the inadequacies of care provided for older people, which prompted a nationwide scandal in the UK in 1976. Although initially official inquiries into these allegations reported that they were "totally unfounded or grossly exaggerated",<ref>'Sans Everything (Reports of Inquiries)' ''Hansard'' HC Deb 9 July 1968 vol 768 cc213–6, 214</ref> her campaigns led to revealing of other instances of ill treatment which were accepted and prompted the government to implement NHS policy changes.<ref name="Anon 1974">Anon, 'Disturbing report on a hospital: health authorities to be asked to review standards of care' ''Times'', 16 May 1974, 16</ref>
As noted above, Councillor Richard Thomas brought up the issue of age discrimination at an early stage at a meeting of Bracknell Forest Council in March 1983. He pointed out it is a double side process, with discrimination working against both older and younger citizens.
So, in the UK, laws against ageism are new. Age discrimination laws were only brought into force in October 2006,<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/legislation/Pages/IntheUK.aspx In the UK] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110326041717/http://www.agediscrimination.info/legislation/Pages/IntheUK.aspx |date=26 March 2011 }}. Agediscrimination.info. Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> and can now be found in the [[Equality Act 2010]]. This implements the Equal Treatment Framework Directive [[2000/78/EC]] and protects employees against direct discrimination, [[indirect discrimination]], [[harassment]] and [[victimisation]]. Pursuant to the [[Equality Act 2010]] it is generally unlawful to discriminate based upon age in the provision of goods and services.<ref>{{cite web |title=Age discrimination - when discrimination is allowed in the provision of goods or services |url=https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/consumer/discrimination-in-the-provision-of-goods-and-services/discrimination-in-the-provision-of-goods-and-services1/goods-and-services-what-are-the-different-types-of-discrimination/what-doesn-t-count-as-unlawful-discrimination-in-goods-and-services/age-discrimination-when-discrimination-is-allowed-in-the-provision-of-goods-or-services/ |website=Citizens Advice |access-date=27 April 2020}}</ref>
Despite the relatively recent{{when|date=December 2020}} prohibition on age discrimination, there have already been many notable cases and official statistics show a 37% increase in claims in 2009/10<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=218 37% rise in age discrimination claims]. Agediscrimination.info (8 July 2010). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> and a further 31% increase in 2010/11.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=470 Age discrimination claims increase by 79%, Tribunal Service statistics show]. Agediscrimination.info (31 March 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> Examples include the case involving Rolls Royce,<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/cases/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=93 ItemPage] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721183803/http://www.agediscrimination.info/cases/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=93 |date=21 July 2011 }}. Agediscrimination.info (14 May 2009). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> the "Heyday" case brought by [[Age UK]]<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/cases/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=114 ItemPage] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721183813/http://www.agediscrimination.info/cases/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=114 |date=21 July 2011 }}. Agediscrimination.info (25 September 2009). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> and the recent{{when|date=December 2020}} [[Miriam O'Reilly]] case against the [[BBC]].<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/cases/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=412 ItemPage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817013151/http://www.agediscrimination.info/cases/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=412 |date=17 August 2011 }}. Agediscrimination.info (10 January 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
Recent{{when|date=December 2020}} research suggested that the number of age discrimination claims annually could reach 15,000 by 2015.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=476 Age discrimination claims will continue to rise and peak at nearly 15,000 a year by 2015]. Agediscrimination.info (7 July 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
The European Social Study survey in 2011 revealed that nearly two out of five people claim to have been shown a lack of respect because of their age. The survey suggested that the UK is riven by intergenerational splits, with half of the people admitting they do not have a single friend over 70; this compares with only a third of Portuguese, Swiss and Germans who say that they do not have a friend of that age or older.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=546 UK among Europe's worst countries for Ageism and age discrimination]. Agediscrimination.info (30 October 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref> A Demos study in 2012 showed that three-quarters of people in the UK believed there to be not enough opportunities for older and younger people to meet and work together.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=637 Older people in Britain are more concerned about age discrimination than their European neighbours]. Agediscrimination.info (25 May 2012). Retrieved on 30 May 2012.</ref>
The "Grey Pride" campaign has been advocating for a Minister for Older People and its campaign has had some success, with Labour Leader [[Ed Miliband]] appointing [[Liz Kendall]] as Shadow Minister for Older People.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=555 Shadow minister for older people is a 'thorn in the side' of the coalition]. Agediscrimination.info (25 October 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
The artist Michael Freedman, an outspoken advocate against age discrimination within the art world says that "mature students, like me, come to art late in life, so why are we penalised and demotivated? Whatever happened to lifelong learning and the notion of a flexible workforce?"<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.michaelfreedman.co.uk/2011/12/ageism-in-the-art-world/|first = Michael|last = Freedman|title = Ageism in the Art World|date = 29 December 2011|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140508205817/http://www.michaelfreedman.co.uk/2011/12/ageism-in-the-art-world/|archive-date = 8 May 2014|access-date = 15 April 2019|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
==Advocacy against ageism== [[File:Child Labor in United States 1910 working night shift.jpg|thumb|A 14-year-old newsboy in [[New York City]], 1910]] The [[Newsboys Strike of 1899]] fought ageist employment practices targeted against youth by large newspaper syndicates in the [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]] of America. The strikers demonstrated across the city for several days, effectively stopping circulation of the two papers, along with the news distribution for many [[New England]] cities. The [[Strike action|strike]] lasted two weeks, causing Pulitzer's ''[[New York World]]'' to decrease its circulation from 360,000 papers sold per day to 125,000.<ref>Nasaw, David. (1999) "Ch. 3: Youse an' yer noble scrap: On strike with the Newsboy Legion in 1899." in ''Big Town, Big Time.'' New York: New York Daily News. p. 9.</ref> Although the price of papers was not lowered, the strike was successful in forcing the ''World'' and ''Journal'' to offer full buybacks to their sellers, thus increasing the amount of money that newsies received for their work.<ref>Mott, F.L. (2000) ''American Journalism''. New York: Routledge. p. 598.</ref>
The [[American Youth Congress]], or AYC, was formed in 1935 to advocate for [[youth rights]] in U.S. politics. It ended in 1940.<ref>Black, A., Hopkins, J. ''et al.'' (2003) [http://www.nps.gov/archive/elro/glossary/american-youth-congress.htm "American Youth Congress,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019032029/http://www.nps.gov/archive/elro/glossary/american-youth-congress.htm |date=October 19, 2007 }} ''The Eleanor Roosevelt Papers.'' Teaching Eleanor Roosevelt. Hyde Park, New York: Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site. Retrieved 7/30/07.</ref> [[File:AARP Pride Booth Boston 2017.png|thumb|[[AARP]] booth at [[Boston]] Pride Festival, 2017]] [[AARP]] was founded in 1958 by [[Ethel Percy Andrus]] (a retired educator from California) and Leonard Davis (later the founder of the [[Colonial Penn Life Insurance Company|Colonial Penn Group]] of insurance companies).<ref>{{cite news|work=Los Angeles Times|url=https://articles.latimes.com/2001/jan/23/local/me-15772|date=January 23, 2001|title=Local: Obituary}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.usc.edu/6078/Obituary-AARP-founder-philanthropist-Leonard-Davis-76/|work=USC News|title=AARP Founder: Philanthropist Leonard Davis, 76}}</ref> Its stated mission is "to empower people to choose how they live as they age".<ref>{{Cite web|url= https://www.aarp.org/about-aarp/|title=About AARP|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> It is an influential [[lobbying]] group in the United States focusing largely on issues affecting the elderly.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thenonprofittimes.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/8-1-15_Top50PI.pdf|title=The 2015 Power & Influence Top 50|date=August 31, 2015|website=The NonProfit Times|publisher=The NonProfit Times}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thehill.com/business-a-lobbying/top-lobbyists/258317-top-lobbyists-2015-grassroots|title=Top Lobbyists 2015: Grassroots|last=Dickson|first=Rebecca|date=October 28, 2015|access-date=2016-09-26}}</ref>
[[Aid for the Elderly in Government Institutions]] (AEGIS) was a British [[pressure group]] that campaigned to improve the care of older people in long-stay wards of [[National Health Service]] [[psychiatric hospitals]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archives.lse.ac.uk/Record.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&id=AEGIS|title=AEGIS - AEGIS (Aid to the Elderly in Government Institutions)|website=LSE Library Services|access-date=2016-05-16}}</ref><ref name="Whitewash">{{Cite news|title=Whitewash in the old folks' wards|last=Robinson|first=Anne|date=5 April 1970|work=Sunday Times}}</ref> The group was founded by [[Barbara Robb]] in 1965,<ref name="Whitewash" /> and was active until her death in 1976.<ref>{{Cite news|title=The patients' campaigner|date=25 June 1976|work=Hampstead and Highgate Express}}</ref>
The [[Gray Panthers]] was formed in 1970 by [[Maggie Kuhn]], with a goal of eliminating [[mandatory retirement]] in the United States; they now work on many [[social justice]] issues including eliminating ageism.<ref>Kuhn, M., Long, C. and Quinn, L. (1991) ''No Stone Unturned: the Life and Times of Maggie Kuhn.'' Ballantine Books.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aarp.org/politics-society/history/champions-of-aging-photos/older-american-maggie-kuhn-gray-panthers.html|title=Maggie Kuhn - Champions of Aging|first=Patrick J.|last=Kiger|website=AARP}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.graypanthersnyc.org/about_us/ |title=About Us |publisher=Gray Panthers Nyc |date=2018-08-27 |access-date=2020-04-25}}</ref>
[[Youth Liberation of Ann Arbor]] started in 1970 to promote youth and fight ageism.
[[Three O'Clock Lobby]] formed in 1976 to promote [[youth participation]] throughout traditionally ageist government structures in Michigan.
Old Lesbians Organizing for Change was founded in 1987; the mission of the organization is to "eliminate the oppression of ageism and to stand in solidarity against all oppressions" through “[the] cooperative community of Old Lesbian feminist activists from many backgrounds working for justice and the well-being of all old lesbians.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/c8z89fjx/|title=Finding Aid for the Old Lesbians Organizing for Change records 1986-1992 LSC.2203|website=oac.cdlib.org}}</ref> Their initial meeting was inspired by the publication of the book ''[https://archive.org/details/isbn_9781883523404 Look Me in the Eye: Old Women, Aging and Ageism]'' by [[Barbara Macdonald]] and Cynthia Rich in 1983.<ref name="ref2">{{cite web | url=http://asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss547_bioghist.html | title=Old Lesbians Organizing for Change Records | access-date=27 March 2015 }}</ref>
[[Americans for a Society Free from Age Restrictions]] formed in 1996 to advance the civil and human rights of young people through eliminating ageist laws targeted against young people, and to help youth counter ageism in America.<ref>{{cite web|work=ASFAR |year=2006 |url=http://www.asfar.org/articles.php |title=Americans for a Society Free from Age Restrictions Articles of Incorporation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070609192032/http://www.asfar.org/articles.php |archive-date=9 June 2007}}</ref> [[File:NYRA Berkeley voting age protest.jpg|thumb|[[National Youth Rights Association]] members protesting the [[Voting age#U|voting age]] in [[Berkeley, California]] (2004)]] The [[National Youth Rights Association]] started in 1998 to promote awareness of the legal and human rights of young people in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|work=National Youth Rights Association|year=2001|url=http://www.youthrights.org/docs/nyraarticlesofinc.pdf|title=National Youth Rights Association Articles of Incorporation (Partial)}}</ref>
The [[Freechild Project]] was formed in 2001 in the United States to identify, unify and promote diverse opportunities for youth engagement in social change by fighting ageism.
===Related campaigns=== Director [[Paul Weitz (filmmaker)|Paul Weitz]] reported he wrote the 2004 film, ''[[In Good Company (2004 film)|In Good Company]]'', to reveal how ageism affects youth and adults.<ref>Hellerman, A. (2005) [http://www.wgaeast.org/features/2005/03/18/paul_weitz/index.html Working Solo in Good Company]{{Dead link|date=May 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Writers Guild of America, East website.</ref>
In 2002 [[The Freechild Project]] created an information and training initiative to provide resources to youth organizations and schools focused on youth rights.<ref>(n.d.) [http://www.freechild.org/SNAYR/index.htm Survey of North American Youth Rights] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206100316/http://www.freechild.org/SNAYR/index.htm |date=6 February 2007 }} The Freechild Project website.</ref>
In 2006 Lydia Giménez-LLort, an assistant professor of Psychiatry and researcher at the [[Autonomous University of Barcelona]] coined the term 'Snow White Syndrome' at the 'Congrés de la Gent Gran de Cerdanyola del Vallès' (Congress of the Elderly of Cerdanyola del Vallès, Barcelona, Spain) as a metaphor to define Ageism in an easier and more friendly way while developing a constructive spirit against it. The metaphor is based on both the auto-Ageism and adultocracy exhibited by the [[Queen (Snow White)|evil queen]] of the [[Snow White]] fairy tale as well as the social Ageism symbolized by the mirror.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saberenvejecer.es/saberhacer_30.html|language=es|title=Envellir bé · Successful Ageing · Saber Envejecer website – Know-how.|access-date=13 May 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425094931/http://www.saberenvejecer.es/saberhacer_30.html|archive-date=25 April 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref>
Since 2008 'The Intergenerational Study' by Lydia Giménez-LLort and Paula Ramírez-Boix from the [[Autonomous University of Barcelona]] is aimed to find the basis of the link between grandparents and grandsons (positive family relationships) that can minimize the Ageism towards the elderly. Students of several Spanish universities have enrolled in this study which soon will be also performed in the US, Nigeria, Barbados, Argentina, and Mexico. The preliminary results reveal that 'The Intergenerational study questionnaire' induces young people to do a reflexive and autocritic analysis of their intergenerational relationships in contrast to those shown towards other unrelated old people which results very positive to challenge Ageism. A cortometrage about 'The International Study' has been directed and produced by Tomás Sunyer from [[Los Angeles City College]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saberenvejecer.es/investigar_25.html|language=es|title=Envellir bé : Successful Ageing · Saber envejecer website – Research.|access-date=13 May 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090423185650/http://www.saberenvejecer.es/investigar_25.html|archive-date=23 April 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref>
[[Votes at 16]] intends to lower the [[voting age]] in the United Kingdom to 16, reducing Ageism and giving 16-year-olds equal pay on the [[National Minimum Wage]]. The group claims that 16-year-olds get less money than older people for the same work, angering many 16-year-olds. They additionally postulate that 16-year-olds will have their voice listened to by older people more often.
Chilean director [[Sebastian Lelio]] created a U.S. version of his acclaimed 2013 film ''[[Gloria (2013 film)|Gloria]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2017/11/will-a-us-adaptation-ruin-sebastian-lelios-gloria/543951/|title=Will a U.S. Adaptation Ruin Sebastian Lelio's Gloria?|last=Abbady|first=Tal|date=26 November 2017|website=The Atlantic|access-date=28 November 2017}}</ref> The original film challenges the notion that as women age they become culturally 'invisible';<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Isopahkala-Bouret|first=Ulpukka|date=2017|title="It's a great benefit to have gray hair!": The intersection of gender, aging, and visibility in midlife professional women's narratives|journal=Journal of Women & Aging|volume=29|issue=3|pages=267–277|doi=10.1080/08952841.2016.1142773|pmid=27629496|s2cid=33967941}}</ref> they may continue to be powerful, desirable, and sexually active. In the 2018 English [[remake]], titled ''[[Gloria Bell]]'', actress [[Julianne Moore]] portrayed the lead character.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cannes-julianne-moore-star-imagining-sebastian-lelios-gloria-1002948|title=Cannes: Julianne Moore to Star in Re-Imagining of Sebastian Lelio's 'Gloria'|last=Ford|first=Rebecca|date=12 May 2017|website=Hollywood Reporter|access-date=28 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Dargis |first1=Manohla |title='Gloria Bell' Review: Love Is in the Air for a Transcendent Julianne Moore |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/07/movies/gloria-bell-review.html |access-date=29 July 2019 |work=The New York Times |date=7 March 2019}}</ref>
===Accusations of ageism=== In a 2005 interview, actor [[Pierce Brosnan]] cited ageism as one of the contributing factors as to why he was not asked to continue his role as [[James Bond]] in the Bond film ''[[Casino Royale (2006 film)|Casino Royale]]'', released in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|last = Cox|first = John|date = 5 November 2005|url = http://commanderbond.net/article/2994|title = Brosnan Bares All For Playboy|website = CommanderBond.net|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060702020428/http://commanderbond.net/article/2994|archive-date = 2 July 2006|access-date = 15 April 2019|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Also, successful singer and actress [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] spoke out in her 50s about ageism and her fight to defy the norms of society.<ref>{{cite web|date = 18 June 2008|url = http://www.carefair.com/html/Madonna_Not_Giving_In_to_Ageism_5301.html|title = Madonna not giving in to Ageism|publisher = Care Fair|url-status = dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20081013071815/http://www.carefair.com/html/Madonna_Not_Giving_In_to_Ageism_5301.html|archive-date = 13 October 2008|access-date = 17 January 2009|df = dmy-all}}</ref> In 2015, [[Radio 1 Madonna controversy|BBC Radio 1 were accused of ageism]] after the station did not add her new single to their playlist. Similarly, ''[[Sex and the City]]'' star [[Kim Cattrall]] has also raised the issue of ageism.<ref>[http://www.agediscrimination.info/News/Pages/ItemPage.aspx?Item=382 Kim Cattrall's red carpet rant: "down with Ageism and age discrimination"]. Agediscrimination.info (5 April 2011). Retrieved on 11 April 2012.</ref>
A 2007 [[Pew Research Center]] study found that a majority of American voters would be less likely to vote for a President past a given age,{{which|date=November 2017}} with 45% saying that age would not matter.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
[[Margaret Morganroth Gullette]]'s 2017 book, ''Ending Ageism or How Not to Shoot Old People'', provides multiple examples to illustrate the pervasiveness of ageism and delivers a call to action.<ref>{{Cite web |url = https://www.wbur.org/artery/2017/08/15/ending-ageism |title = Who Are You Calling Old? Brandeis Scholar Argues For An End To Ageism |author = Erin Trahan |date = 15 August 2017 |publisher = The ARTery}}</ref>
